Key Arguments: The bill creates two classes of citizens, privileging politicians, journalists, and educational institutions over regular citizens.
Excessive fines will lead digital service providers to adopt overly restrictive speech policies.
Determining true or false information is challenging and ever-evolving, as demonstrated by the COVID-19 pandemic.
The bill targets not only false information but also 'misleading' or 'deceptive' information, which could stifle free speech.
Delegating legislative power to private entities violates constitutional accountability and freedom of political communication.
The bill could restrict citizens' access to vital information needed for informed voting decisions.
It could disproportionately favor government-endorsed publications and stifle independent media and critical perspectives.
The bill contradicts Australia's commitment to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the Constitution's recognition of freedom of expression.
Notable Quotes: I am alarmed by this proposed bill, which in my view demonstrates a lack of respect for the freedom of speech of Australian citizens.
The determination of what is considered true or false information is an incredibly challenging and ever-evolving task.
Delegating legislative power to private entities violates the constitutional principle of accountability.
This bill threatens the freedom of speech that is vital to our democracy and unfairly discriminates against regular citizens.
